titleStmt.title: Wilson, Robert, d. 1600 : : The three ladies of London (1584) a machine-readable transcription of the 1584 Quarto

publicationStmt.publisher: Robert Wilson, d. 1600 (fl.1572-1600) A right excellent and famous Comoedy called the three Ladies of London. Wherein is notablie declared and set foorth, how by the meanes of Lucar, Loue and Conscience is so corrupted, that the one is married to Dissimulation, the other fraught withall abhomination. A perfect patterne for all Estates to looke into, and a worke right worthie to be marked. Written by R. W. as it hath beene publiquely played. London Printed by Roger Warde [etc.] 1584

sourceDesc.p:
Play details
The three ladies of London. Genre: Moralities. Date first published: 1584. Date first performed: 1581 ?
A Right Excellent Comoedy called The Three Ladies of London, STC 25784, Hungtington Library copy, reproduced on microfilm in the UMI Early English Books series

encodingDesc.p: The characters are identified by IDREF pointing to information in the following declarations. Fame Love Conscience Dissimulation Simplicity Fraud Simony Usury Lady Lucre Mercadore Artifex Creticus Sincerity Hospitality Sir Nicholas Nemo Sir Peter Pleaseman Gerontus Cogging Tom Beggar Wily Will Prologue Multiple Speakers Song Judge Sir Nicholas Nemo Sir Peter Pleaseman Gerontus Cogging The Clerk of the Assize The Crier

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by IDREF which point to the following.

sp.speaker: Prologue.
sp.l: To sit on honours seat, it is a lofty reach,
To seek for praise by making brags, oft-times doth get a breach.
We list not ride the rolling Racks, that dims the crystal skies,
We mean to set no glimmering glance before your courteous eyes.
We search not Pluto's pensive pit, nor taste of Limbo lake:
We do not show of warlike fight, as sword and shield to shake.
We speak not of the powers divine, ne yet of furious sprites:
We do not seek high hills to climb, nor talk of loves delights.
We do not here present to you, the thresher with his flail:
Ne do we here present to you, the milkmaid with her pail.
We show not you of country toil, as hedger with his bill:
We do not bring the husbandman, to lop and top with skill.
We play not here the Gardeners part, to plant, to set and sow:
You marvel then what stuff we have to furnish out our show.
Your patience yet we crave a while, till we have trimmed our stall:
Then young and old come and behold our wares, and buy them all.
Then if our wares shall seem to you, well woven, and good and fine,
We hope we shall your custom have , again another time.

body.stage:
The first acte.
Enter Fame sounding before Loue and Conscience.

sp.speaker: Loue.
sp.l:
Lady Conscience, what shall we say to our estates,
to whom shall we complain?
Or how shall we abridge such fates, as heapeth up our pain?
It is Lucre now that rules the rout, it is she is all in all:
It is she that holds her head so stout, in fine it is she that works our fall.
O Conscience, I fear, I fear a day,
That we by her and usury, shall quite be cast away.

sp.speaker: Consci.
sp.l: Indeed I fear the worst, for every man doth sew,
And comes from countries strange and far, of her to have a view.
Although they ought to seek true Love and Conscience clear:
But Love and Conscience few do like, that lean on Lucre's chair.
Men ought be ruled by us , we ought in them bear sway:
So should each neighbour live by other, in good estate always.

sp.speaker: Loue.
sp.l: For Lucre men come from Italy, Barbary, Turkey,
From Jury: nay the Pagan himself ,
Endangers his body to gape for her pelf.
They forsake mother, Prince, Country, Religion, kith and kin,
Nay men care not what they forsake, so Lady Lucre they win.
That we poor ladies may sigh to see, our states thus turned and tossed,
And worse and worse is like to be, where Lucre rules the roost.

sp.speaker: Consci.
sp.l: You say the truth, yet God I trust will not admit it so:
That Love and Conscience by Lucre's lust, shall catch an overthrow.

sp.speaker: Fame.
sp.l: Good Ladies rest content, and you no doubt shall see,
Them plagued with painful punishment for such their cruelty.
And if true Love and Conscience live , from Lucre's lust lascivious:
Then Fame a triple crown will give , which lasteth aye victorious.

sp.speaker: Consci.
sp.l: God grant that Conscience keep within the bounds of right:
And that vile Lucre do not daunt, her heart with deadly spite.

sp.speaker: Loue.
sp.l: And grant O God that Love be found in City, Town, and Country,
Which causeth wealth and peace abound, and pleaseth God almighty.

sp.speaker: Fame.
sp.l: But Ladies, is it your pleasure to walk abroad a while,
And recreate yourselves with measure your sorrows to beguile.

sp.speaker: Consci.
sp.l: Pass on good Fame, your steps do frame, on you we will attend,
And pray to God that holds the rod, our states, for to defend.

body.stage:
(Exeunt.)
The second Act.
Enter Dissimulation, hauing on a Farmers long coat, and
a cappe, and his powle and beard painted motley.

sp.speaker: Dissim.
sp.l: NAy no less than a Farmer, a right honest man,
But my tongue cannot stay me to tell what I am:
Nay who is it that knows me not by my parti-coloured head?
They may well think that see me, my honesty is fled.
Tush a fig for honesty, tut let that go !
Sith men, women, and children my name and doings do know,
My name is Dissimulation, and no base mind I bear,
For my outward effects my inward zeal do declare:
For men do dissemble with their wives, and their wives with them again,
So that in the hearts of them I always remain:
The child dissembles with his father, and sister with his brother,
The maiden with her mistress, and the young man with his lover:
There is Dissimulation between neighbour and neighbour,
Friend and Friend one with another .
Between the servant and his Master, between brother and brother,
Then why make you it strange that ever you knew me,
Seeing so often I range throughout every degree?
But I forget my business, I will towards London as fast as I can,
To get entertainment of one of the three ladies, like an honest man.

body.stage:
Enter Simplicitie lyke a Miller all mealy with
wande in his hand.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.l: They say that there is preferment in London to have ,
Master if there be I will be passing and brave:
Why I will be no more a miller, because the maidens call me dusty pole,
One thumps me on the neck, and another strikes me on the nose:
And you see I am a handsome fellow mark the comporknaunce of my stature.
Faith I will go seek peradventures, and be a serving-creature.

sp.speaker: Dissim.
sp.l: Wither away good fellow I pray thee declare.

sp.speaker: Sympli.
sp.l: Marry I will clare thee, to London, would thou didst go there.

sp.speaker: Dissim.
sp.l: What if I did, would it be the better for thee?

sp.speaker: Simpli.
sp.l: Aye marry should it, for I love honest company.

sp.speaker: Dissim.
sp.l: Agreed, there is a bargain, but what shall I call thee?

sp.speaker: Simpli.
sp.l: Cause thou art an honest man I will tell thee, my name is Simplicity.

sp.speaker: Dissim.
sp.l: A name agreeing to thy nature, but stay here comes more company.

body.stage: Enter Fraud with a Sword and a Buckler like a Ruffian.

sp.speaker: Fraud.
sp.l: Huff once aloft and if I may hit in the right vain,
Where I may beguile easily without any great pain:
I will flaunt it and brave it after the lusty swash,
I will deceive thousands, what care I who lie in the lash.

sp.speaker: Dissim.
sp.l: What Fraud well met, whither travellest thou this way?

sp.speaker: Fraud.
sp.l: To London to get entertainment there if I may,
Of the three Ladies, Lucre, Love , and Conscience:
I care not whom I serve (the Devil) so I may get pence.

sp.speaker: Simpli.
sp.l: O Fraud I know thee for a deceitful knave,
And art thou gotten so baniacion and brave:
I knew thee when thou dwelledest at a place called Graves-end,
And the guests knew thee too, because thou wast not their friend:
For when thou shouldest bring reckoning to the guests,
Thou wouldst say twice so much, and swear it cost thy dame no less,
So thou didst deceive them, and thy dame too:
And because they spied thy knavery, away thou didst go.
Then thou didst go into Hartforshire, to a place called Ware,
And because horses stood at hay for a penny a night there,
So that thou couldst get nothing that kind of way,
Thou didst grease the horses teeth, that they should not eat hay,
Then thou wouldst tell the rider his horse no hay would eat.
Then the man would say, give him some other kind of meat.
Sir, shall I give him Oats, Fishes, Peas, Barley, or Bread,
But whatever thou gavest him, thou stolest three quarters when he was in bed.
But I think one day thou wilt not be proud of the Rope and the Cart.
Take a wise fellows counsel Fraud, leave thy cozening and filching.

sp.speaker: Fraude.
sp.l: Thou whoreson rascal swad avaunt, I will bang thee for thy brawling,
How darest thou defame a Gentleman that hath so large a living?

sp.speaker: Simpli.
sp.l: A goodly Gentleman Ostler, I think none of all you will believe him.

sp.speaker: Fraude.
sp.l: What a clynchpoop drudge is this? I can forbear him no more.

body.stage:
Let Fraude made as though he would strike him, but let
Dissimulation step betwene them.

sp.speaker: Dissim.
sp.l: My good friend Fraud refrain, and care not therefore,
It is Simplicity that patch, he knoweth not good from bad.
And to stand in contention with him, I would think you were mad.
But tell me Fraud tell me, hast thou been an Ostler in thy days?

sp.speaker: Fraude.
sp.l: Tut I have proved an hundred such ways:
For when I could not thrive by all other trades,
I became a Squire to wait upon Jades.
But then was then, and now is now, but let that pass,
I am as thou seest me, what care I the devil what I was.

sp.speaker: Dissim.
sp.l: You say you go to London, i'faith have with you then.

sp.speaker: Simpli.
sp.l: Nay come and go with me good honest man.
For if thou go with him, he will teach thee all his knavery,
There is none will go with him, that hath any honesty.
A bots on thy motley beard, I know thee, thou art Dissimulation,
And hast thou got an honest man's coat, to semble this fashion.
I will tell thee what, thou wilt even semble and cog with thine own father,
A couple of false knaves together, a Thief and a Broker.
Thou makest towns folks believe, that thou art an honest man in the country,
Thou dost nothing but cog, lie, and foist with hypocrisy.
You shall be hanged together, and go alone together for me,
For if I should go, the folks would say, we were knaves all three.

body.stage: Enter Simony and Usury hand in hand.

sp.speaker: Symo.
sp.l: Friend Usury, I think we are well near at our journeys end:
But knowest thou whom I have espied?

sp.speaker: Vsery.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: Fraud our great friend.

sp.speaker: Vsury.
sp.l: And I see another that is now come into my remembrance.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: Who is that?

sp.speaker: Vsury.
sp.l: Marry Master. Dauy Dissimulation, a good helper, and our old acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Simpli.
sp.l: Now all the Cards in the stock are dealt about,
The four knaves in a cluster comes ruffling out.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: What Fraud and Dissimulation happily found out,
I marvel what piece of work you two go about.

sp.speaker: Fraud.
sp.l: Faith sir we met by chance, and towards London are bent.

sp.speaker: Vsery.
sp.l: And to London we hie it is our chiefest intent,
To see if we can get entertainment of the Ladies or no.

sp.speaker: Dissim.
sp.l: And for the selfsame matter even thither we go .

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: Then we are luckily well met, and seeing we wish all for one thing,
I would we our wills and wishing might win.

sp.speaker: Simpli.
sp.l: Yes they will be sure to win the Devil and all,
Or else they will make a man to spew out his gall:
O that vild Usury, he lent my father a little money, and for breaking one day
He took the fee-simple of his house and mill quite away:
And yet he borrowed not half a quarter so much as it cost,
But I think if he had had but a shilling it had been lost:
So he killed my father with sorrow, and undoed me quite,
If you deal with him sirs you shall find him a knave full of spite.
And Simony aye pse aye , Simony too he is a knave for the nonce.
He loves to have twenty livings at once,
And if he let an honest man as I am to have one,
He will let it so dear that he shall be undone:
And he seeks to get Parsons livings into his hand,
And puts in some odd dunce that to his payment will stand:
So if the parsonage be worth forty or fifty pound a year,
He will give one twenty nobles to mumble service once a month there.
What rascal is he that speaketh by us such villainy.

sp.speaker: Dissim.
sp.p:
Sirs he was at us erewhile too, it is no matter, it is a simple soul
called Simplicity.

sp.speaker: Fraud.
sp.l: But here come two of the Ladies therefore make ready.
But which of us all shall first break the matter?

sp.speaker: Dissim.
sp.l: Marry let Simony do it, for he finely can flatter.

sp.speaker: Vsery.
sp.l: Nay sirs because none of us shall have pre-eminence above other:
We will sing in fellowship together like brother and brother.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: Of troth agreed my masters let it be so.

sp.speaker: Simpli.
sp.l: Nay if they sing, I will sing too.

l.emph: Good Ladies take pity and grant our desire.
Speak boldly and tell me what is it you require.
Your service good Ladies, is that we do crave.
We like not, nor list not such servants to have .
If you entertain us , we trusty will be:

sp.l: But if you refrain us , then most unhappy.
We will come, we will run, we will bend at your beck:
We will ply, we will hie, for fear of your check.

l.emph: You do fain, you do flatter, you do lie, you do prate,

sp.l: You will steal, you will Rob, you will kill in your hate.
I deny you, I defy you, then cease of your talking:
I refrain you, I disdain you, therefore get you walking.

sp.speaker: Consci.
sp.l: What Fraud, Dissimulation, Usury, and Simony,
How dare you for shame presume so boldly
As once to show yourselves before Love and Conscience,
Not yielding your lewd lives first to repentance?
Think you not that God will plague you for your wicked practises,
If you intend not to amend your vild lives so amiss?
Think you not God knows your thoughts, words and works,
And what secret mischiefs in the hearts of you lurks?
Then how dare you to offend his heavenly majesty,
With your dissembling deceit, your flattery and your usury?

sp.speaker: Fraud.
sp.l: Tut sirs, seeing Lady Conscience is so scippolous,
Let us not speak to her, for I see it is frivolous:
But what say you Lady Love , will you grant us favour?

sp.speaker: Loue.
sp.l: I will no such servants, so ill of behaviour:
Servants more fitter for Lucre than Love ,
And happy are they which refrain for to prove:
Shameless, pitiless, graceless, and quite past honesty,
Then who of good conscience, but will hate your company.

sp.speaker: Vsery.
sp.l: Here is Scipolous Conscience, and nice Love indeed,
Tush if they will not other will, I know we shall speed.

sp.speaker: Simpli.
sp.l: But Lady I stand still behind, for I am none of their company.

sp.speaker: Consci.
sp.l: Why, what art thou? o I know thou art Simplicity.

sp.speaker: Simpli.
sp.l: Aye faith, I am Simplicity, and would fain serve ye .

sp.speaker: Consci.
sp.l: No, I may have no fools to dwell with me.

sp.speaker: Simpli.
sp.l: Why, then Lady Love will you have me then ?

sp.speaker: Loue.
sp.l: Aye Simplicity thou shalt be my man.

sp.speaker: Simpli.
sp.l: But shall I be your good man?

sp.speaker: Loue.
sp.l: Aye my good man indeed.

sp.speaker: Simpli.
sp.l: Aye but I would be your good man, and sway up a wedding with good speed.

sp.speaker: Loue.
sp.l: No, Love may not marry in any case with Simplicity,
But if thou wilt serve me, I will receive thee willingly,
And if thou wilt not, what remedy.

sp.speaker: Simpli.
sp.l: Yes I will serve ye, but will you go into dinner for I am hungry?

sp.speaker: Loue.
sp.l: Come Lady Conscience, pleaseth you to walk home from this company?

sp.speaker: Consci.
sp.l: With right good will, for their sights pleaseth not me.

sp.speaker: Simpli.
sp.l: Fraud is the cloxbish knave, and Usury the hardhearted knave:
And Simony the diamond dainty knave,
And Dissimulation the spiteful knave of Spade.
Come there any more knaves, come there any more :
I see four knaves stand in a row.

body.stage:
Let Fraud runne at him, and let Simplicitie runne in, and
come out again straight.

sp.speaker: Fraud.
sp.l: Away Drudge be gone quickly.

sp.speaker: Simpli.
sp.l: I wous do thrust out my eyes with a Lady.

sp.speaker: Vsery.
sp.l: Did you ever see Gentlemen so rated at before,
But it skills not, I hope one day to turn them both out of door.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: We are arrantly flouted, railed at, and scoffed in our kind,
That same Conscience is a vild terror to man's mind:
Yet faith I care not, for I have borne many more than these,
When I was conversant with the Clergy beyond the Seas:
And he that will live in this world must not care what such say,
For they are blossoms blown down, not to be found after May.

sp.speaker: Fraud.
sp.l: Faith care that care will, for I care not a point,
I have shift it hitherto, and whilst I live I will ieoberd a joint:
And at my death I will leave my inheritor behind,
That shall be of the right stamp to follow my mind:
Therefore let them prate till their hearts ache, and spit out their evil,
She cannot quail me if she came in likeness of the great devil.

sp.speaker: Dissim.
sp.l: Mass Fraud thou hast a doughty heart to make a hangman of ,
For thou hast good skill to help men from the coff:
But we were arrantly flouted, yet I thought she had not known me,
But I perceive though Dissimulation do disguise him, Conscience can see.
What though Conscience perceive it, all the world cannot beside?
Tush there be a thousand places where we ourselves may provide:
But look sirs here cometh a lusty Lady towards us in haste,
But speak to her if you will, that we may be all placed.

sp.speaker: Vsery.
sp.l: I Pray thee do, for thou art the likeliest to speed.

sp.speaker: Dissim.
sp.l: Why then I will to it with a stomach in hope of good speed.
Fair Lady, all the Gods of good fellowship kiss ye (I would say bliss ye. )

sp.speaker: Lucar.
sp.l: Thou art very pleasant and full of thy rope-ripe (I would say Rhetoric.)

sp.speaker: Dissim.
sp.l: Lady you took me at the worst, I beseech you therefore
To pardon my boldness, offending no more.

sp.speaker: Lucar.
sp.l: We do, the matter is not great, but what wouldst thou have ?
How shall I call thee, and what is it thou dost crave?

sp.speaker: Dissim.
sp.l: I am called Dissimulation, and my earnest request
Is to crave entertainment for me and the rest:
Whose names are Fraud, Usury and Simony,
Great carers for your health, wealth, and prosperity.

sp.speaker: Lucar.
sp.l: Fraud, Dissimulation, Usury and Simony,
How truly I thank you for proffering your service to me:
You are all heartily welcome, and I will appoint straight way,
Where each one in his office in great honour shall stay:
But Usury didst thou never know my Grandmother the old Lady Lucre of Uenice.

sp.speaker: Vsury.
sp.l: Yes Madam I was servant her and lived there in bliss.

sp.speaker: Lucar.
sp.l: But why camest thou into England, seeing Uenis is a City
Where Usury by Lucre may live in great glory?

sp.speaker: Vsery.
sp.l: I have often heard your good grandmother tell,
That she had in England a daughter, which her far did excel:
And that England was such a place for Lucre to bide,
As was not in Europe and the whole world beside:
Then lusting greatly to see you, the country, and she being dead,
I made haste to come over to serve you in her stead.

sp.speaker: Lucar.
sp.p:
Gramercy Usury, and I doubt not but that you shall live here as pleasantly,
and pleasanter too, if it may be, but Simony from whence
came ye, tell me.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l:
My birth, nursery, and bringing up hitherto, hath been in Rome, that
ancient Religious City:

On a time, the Monks and Fryers made a banquet, whereunto they
invited me:

With certain other some English Merchants which belike were
of their familiarity.
So talking of many matters, amongst others, one began to debate,
Of the abundant substance still brought to that state:
Some said the increase of their substance and wealth,
Came from other Princes, and brought thither by stealth.
But the Friars and Monks, with all the ancient company,
Said that it first came, and is now upholden by me Simony:
Which the English Merchants gave ear to: then they flattered a little too much
As English men can do for advantage, when increase it doth touch.
And being a-shipboard merry, and overcome with drink on a day,
The wind served, they hoist sail, and so brought me away:
And landing here, I heard in what great estimation you were,
Made bold to your honour to make me repair.

sp.speaker: Lucar.
sp.l: Well Simony I thank thee, but as for Fraud and Dissimulation,
I know their long continuance and after what fashion:
Therefore Dissimulation, you shall be my Steward,
An office that every man's case by you must be preferred.

And you Fraud shall be my rent-gatherer, my letter of Leases and my
purchaser of Land,
So that many old bribes will come to thy hand.

And Usury because I know you to be trusty, you shall be my
Secretary,
To deal amongst Merchants, to bargain and exchange money.
And Simony because you are a sly fellow, and have your tongue liberal,
I will place you over such matters as are Ecclesiastical.
And though I appoint sundry offices where now you are in,
Yet jointly I mean to use you together oft times in one thing.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Lady we rest at your command in aught we can or may.

sp.speaker: Lucar.
sp.l: Then Master Dauy to my Pallas haste thee away ,
And will crafty Conveyance my Butler to make ready

The best fare in my house to welcome thee and thy
company.
But stay Dissimulation, I myself will go with thee:
Gentlemen I will go before, but pray in any case
So soon as ye please resort to my place.

sp.speaker: Symo.
sp.l: I warrant you Lady, we will not long absent be,

sp.speaker: Vsery.
sp.l: Fellow Simony this fell out pat, so well as heart could wish,
We are cunning Anglers, we have caught the fattest fish.
I perceive it is true that her grandmother told,
Here is good to be done, by use of silver and gould:
And sith I am so well settled in this Country,
I will pinch all , rich and poor that come to me.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: And sirrah when I was at Rome, and dwelt in the Friary,
They would talk how England yearly sent over a great mass of money:
And that this little Island was more worth to the Pope,
Than three bigger Realms, which had a great deal more scope.
For here were smoke pence, Peter pence, and Poll pence to be paid,
Besides much other money that to the Popes use was made:
Why it is but lately, since the Pope received this fine,
Not much more than 26. years, it was in Queen Maries time.
But I think England had never known what this gear had meant,
If Friar Austen from the Pope had not hither been sent:

For the Pope hearing it to be a little Island, sent him with a great
army over ,

And winning the victory, he landed about Rye, Sandwich
or Dover.
Then he erected Laws, having the people in subjection,
So for the most part, England hath paid tribute so long:
I hearing of the great store, and wealth in the Country,
Could not choose but persuade myself the people loved Simony.

sp.speaker: Vsery.
sp.l: But stay your talk till some other time, we forget my Lady.

sp.speaker: Symo.
sp.l: Of troth you say true: for she bad us make haste,
But my talk methought favoured well, and had a good taste.

body.stage:
Exeunt ambo.
Enter Mercadore like an Italian Merchant.

sp.speaker: Merca.
sp.l: I judge in my mind that me be not very far
From the place where dwells my Lady Lucre:
But he come an gentleman so he do.
Gentleman, I pray you heartily let me speak you,
Pray you do you not know a gentleman that Master Dauy do call?

sp.speaker: Dissim.
sp.l: Yes marry do I, I am he, and what would you withal?

sp.speaker: Merca.
sp.l: Good my friend Master Dauy, help me I pray you heartily,
For some acquaintance with Madonna Lucre your Lady:

sp.speaker: Dissim.
sp.l: Sir upon condition I will, therefore I would you should know,
That on me and my fellows you must largely bestow:
Whose names are Fraud, Usury, and Simony men of great credit and calling
And to get my Ladies good will and theirs it is no small thing:
But tell me can you be content to win Lucre by Dissimulation?

sp.speaker: Merca.
sp.l: Good my friend do axa me no shush a question,
For he that will live in the world, must be of the world sure,
And the world will love his own, so long as the world endure.

sp.speaker: Dissim.
sp.l: I commend your wit Sir, but here comes my Lady.

sp.speaker: Merca.
sp.l: Come hither here is two tree Crowns for the speak me.

sp.speaker: Dissim.
sp.l: Well sir I thank you, I will go speak for you.

sp.speaker: Lucar.
sp.l: Master Dauy Dissimulation what new acquaintance have ye get there?

sp.speaker: Dissim.
sp.l: Such a one Madam that your state hath great care:
And surely in my mind the Gentleman is worthy,
To be well thought on for his liberality, bounty, and great care to seek ye .

sp.speaker: Lucar.
sp.l: Gentleman you are heartily welcome, how are you called, I pray you tell us ?

sp.speaker: Merca.
sp.l: Madonna, me be a Merchant and be called Senior Merkadorus.

sp.speaker: Lucar.
sp.l: But I pray you tell me what Countryman.

sp.speaker: Merca.
sp.l: Me be Madonna an Italian.

sp.speaker: Lucar.
sp.l: Yet let me trouble ye, I beseech ye whence came ye?

sp.speaker: Merca.
sp.l: For sarua voutra boungrace, me come from Turkey.

sp.speaker: Lucar.
sp.l: Gramercy, but senior Mercadore, dare you not to undertake,
Secretly to convey good commodities out of this country for my sake?

sp.speaker: Merca.
sp.l: Madonna, me do for love of you think no pain too much ,
And to do anything for you me will not grutch:
Me will forsake my Father, Moder, King, Country and more than that .
Me will lie and forswear myself for a quarter so much as my hat.
What is that for love of Lucre me dare or will not do :

Me care not for all the world, the great Devil, nay make my God angry
for you.

sp.speaker: Lucar.
sp.l: You say well Mercadorus, yet Lucre by this is not thoroughly won,
But give ear and I will show, what by thee must be done:

Thou must carry over Wheat, Peas, Barley, Oats, and Fishes and
all kind of grain,

Which is well sold beyond sea, and bring such Merchants great
gain.

Then thou must carry beside Leather, Tallow, Beef, Bacon Belmettell
and everything .

And for these good commodities, trifles to England thou must
bring.

As Bugles to make babbles, coloured bones, glass, beads, to make bracelets
withal:

For every day Gentlewomen in England do ask for such trifles from
stall to stall.

And you must bring more, as Amber, Jet, Coral, Crystal, and every
such babble,
That is slight, pretty and pleasant, they care not to have it profitable.
And if they demand wherefore your wares and merchandise agree,
You must say Jet will take up a straw, Amber will make one fat,
Coral will look pale when you be sick, and Crystal will staunch blood.
So with lying, flattering, and glossing you must utter your ware,
And you shall win me to your will, if you can deceitfully swear.

sp.speaker: Merca.
sp.l:
Think ye not that me have carried over corn, Ledar, Beef and Bacon
too all this while:
And brought hedar many babbles these country men to beguile?
Yes, shall me tell you Madonna, me and my countryman's have sent over ,
bell metal for make ordinance, yea and ordinance itself beside,
That my country, and other countries be so well furnished as this country,
and has never been spied.

sp.speaker: Lucar.
sp.l: Now I perceive you love me, and if you continue in this still,
You shall not only be with me, but command me when and where you will .

sp.speaker: Merca.
sp.l: Lady, for to do all this , and more for you, me be content:
But I think some scall knave will put a bill in the Parliament

For that such
tings shall not be brought here.

sp.speaker: Lucar.
sp.l: Tush Mercadore, I warrant thee, thou needst not to fear:
What if one do? there is some other will flatter and say,
They do no hurt to the country, and with a sleight fetch that bill away.
And if they do not so, that by act of Parliament it be past,
I know you Merchants have many a sleight and subtle cast.
So that you will by stealth bring over great store:
And say it was in the Realm a long time before.
For being so many of these trifles here as there are at this day,
You may increase them at pleasure, when you sent over sea.
And do but give the searcher an odd bribe in his hand,
I warrant you he will let you scape roundly with such things in and out the land:
But Senior Mercadore, I pray you walk in with me,
And as I find you kind to me, so will I favour ye.

sp.speaker: Merca.
sp.p:
Me thank my good Lady. But Master. Dissimulation, here is for your
fellows, Fraud, Usury, and Simony, and say me give it them.

sp.speaker: Dissim.
sp.l: Aye marry Sir, these bribes have welcome been,
Good faith I perceive Dissimulation, Fraud, Usury, and Simony shall live ,
In spite of Love and Conscience, though their hearts it doth grieve.
Mass masters, he that cannot lie, cog, dissemble, and flatter nowadays ,
Is not worthy to live in the world, nor in the Court to have praise.

sp.speaker: Artifex.
sp.l: I beseech you good Master. Dissimulation, befriend a poor man,
To serve Lady Lucre, and sure sir I will consider it hereafter if I can.

sp.speaker: Dissim.
sp.l: What consider me? dost thou think that I am a bribe-taker ?
Faith it lies not in me to further thy matter.

sp.speaker: Artifex.
sp.l: Good Master. Dissimulation help me, I am almost quite undone,
But yet my living hitherto with good Conscience I have won.
But my true working, my early rising, and my late going to bed,
Is scant able to find myself , wife and children dry bread:
For there be such a sort of strangers in this country,
That work fine to please the eye, though it be deceitfully,
And that which is slight, and seems to the eye well,
Shall sooner than a piece of good work be proffered to sell.
And our englishmen be grown so foolish and nice,
That they will not give a penny above the ordinary price.

sp.speaker: Dissim.
sp.l: Faith I cannot help thee, it is my fellow Fraud must pleasure thee.
Here comes my fellow Fraud, speak to him, and I will do what I can.

sp.speaker: Artifex.
sp.l: I beseech you be good me right honest Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Fraude.
sp.l: Why and whereto? what wouldst thou have me do?

sp.speaker: Artifex.
sp.l: That my poor estate you will so much prefer:
As to get me to be a workman to Lady Lucre.
And Sir I doubt not but to please you so well for your pain,
That you shall think very well of me, if I in her service remain.

sp.speaker: Dissim.
sp.l: Good fellow Fraud do so much, for I see he is very willing to live ,
And some piece of work to thee for thy pains he will give .

sp.speaker: Fraud.
sp.l: Well upon that condition I will, but I care not so much for his gifts,
As that he will by my name declare how he came by his great thrifts.
And that he will set out in every kind of thing,
That Fraud is a good husband, and great profit doth bring.
Therefore the next piece of work that thou dost make,
Let me see how deceitful thou wilt do it for my sake.

sp.speaker: Artifex.
sp.l: Yes sir I will sir, of that be you sure,
I will honour your name, while life doth endure.

sp.speaker: Dissim.
sp.l: Fellow Fraud, here comes a Citizen as I deem.

sp.speaker: Fraude.
sp.l: Nay rather a Lawyer, or some pettifogger he doth seem.

sp.speaker: Lawyer.
sp.l: Gentlemen, my earnest suite is to desire ye ,
That your Ladies service you would help me :
For I am an Attorney of the Law, and pleader at the Bar,
And have a great desire to plead for Lady Lucre.
I have been earnest Sir, as is needful in such a case,
For fear another come before me, and obtain my place.
I have pleaded for Love and Conscience till I was weary,

I had many Clients, and many matters, that made my purse light, and
my heart heavy.
Therefore let them plead for Conscience that list for me,
I will plead no more for such as brings nothing but beggary.

sp.speaker: Dissim.
sp.l: Sir upon this condition that you will keep men in the Law,
Ten or twelve years for matters that are not worth a straw.
And that you will make an ill matter seem good, and firmable indeed,
Faith I am content for my part you shall speed.

sp.speaker: Fraude.
sp.l: Nay fellow, thou knowest that Simony and Usury hath an ill matter in law at this time,
Now if thou canst handle the matter so subtle and fine,
As to plead that ill matter good and firmable at the Bar,
Then thou shalt show thyself worthy to win Lady Lucre.
Therefore tell me if you can and will do it or no.
If you do it, be sure to get my Ladies good will ere you go .

sp.speaker: Dissim.
sp.l: By my honesty well remembered, I had quite forgot,
It is about that, a fortnight ago fell out the matter I wot.

sp.speaker: Lawier.
sp.l: Tush Sir, I can make black white, and white black again ,
Tut he that will be a Lawyer, must have a thousand ways to fain.
And many times we Lawyers do one befriend another,
And let good matters slip, tut we agree like brother and brother.
Why Sir what shall let us to wrest and turn the Law as we list?
Seeing we have them printed in the palms of our fist.
Therefore doubt you not, but make bold report,
That I can, and will plead their ill cause in good kind of sort.

sp.speaker: Fraude.
sp.l: Of troth how likest thou this fellow Dissimulation?

sp.speaker: Dissim.
sp.l: Marry I like him well, he is a cunning Clarke, and one of our profession.
But come Sir go with us and we will prefer you.

sp.speaker: Artifex.
sp.l: Good Master. Fraud remember me.

sp.speaker: Fraude.
sp.l: Leave thy prating, I will I tell thee.

sp.speaker: Artifex.
sp.l: Good Master. Dissimulation think on me.

sp.speaker: Dissim.
sp.l: Thou art too importunate and greedy.

sp.speaker: Fraude.
sp.l: Come after dinner, or some other time when we are at leisure.

sp.speaker: Artifex.
sp.l: Come after dinner or some other time, I think so indeed,
For full little do they think of a poor man's need.
These fellows will do nothing for pity and love,
And thrice happy are they that hath no need them to prove.
God he knows the world is grown to such a stay,
That men must use Fraud and Dissimulation too, or beg by the way.
Therefore I will do as the most doth, the fewest shall laugh me to scorn,
And be a fellow amongst good fellows to hold by Saint. Lukes horn.

sp.speaker: Sincer.
sp.l: Good cousin Simplicity do somewhat for me.

sp.speaker: Sympli.
sp.l: Yes faith cousin Sincerity, I will do anything for thee.
What wouldst for me do for thee canst tell that?

Mass I cannot tell what shouldest do for me, except thou wouldst give
me a new hat.

sp.speaker: Sincer.
sp.l: Alas I am not able to give thee a new.

sp.speaker: Simpli.
sp.l: Why I marvel then how thou dost do .
Dost thou get thy living amongst beggars from door to door?
Indeed cousin Sincerity, I had thought thou wast not so poor.

sp.speaker: Sincer.
sp.l: Nay cousin Simplicity, I got my living hardly, but yet I hope just,
And with good Conscience too, although I am restrained from my lust.
But this is it cousin Simplicity, I would request you to do for me:
Which is, to get Lady Love , and Lady Conscience hand to a letter:

That by their means I may get some Benefice to make me live the
better.

sp.speaker: Simpli.
sp.l: Yes I will do so much for thee cousin, but hast thou any here ?

sp.speaker: Sincer.
sp.l: Aye , behold, they are ready drawn, if assigned they were,

body.stage:
Let Simplicitie make as though he read it, and looke quite
ouer, meane while let Conscience enter.

sp.speaker: Sympli.
sp.l: Let me see cousin, for I can read:
Mass it is bravely done, didst thou it indeed?
Mistress Conscience, I have a matter to bequest you too.

sp.speaker: Consci.
sp.l: What is it? I doubt not but it is some wise thing if it be for you.

sp.speaker: Simpli.
sp.l: Marry my cousin Sincerity, would desire to scribe these papers here,
That he may get some preferment, but I know not where.

sp.speaker: Consci.
sp.l: Be these your letters? what would you have me do, and how shall I call ye ?

sp.speaker: Sincer.
sp.l: Lady, my name is Sincerity.

sp.speaker: Consci.
sp.l: And from whence come ye ?

sp.speaker: Sincer.
sp.l: I came from Oxford: but in Cambridge I studied late,
Having nothing, thought good if I could, to make better my state.
But if I had instead of Divinity, the Law, Astronomy, Astrology,

Physiognomy, Palmistry, Arithmetic, Logic, Music, Physic, or
any such thing,
I had not doubted then, but to have had some better living.
But Divines that preach the word of God sincerely and truly,
Are in these days little or nothing at all set by.
God grant the good Preachers be not taken away for our unthankfulness,

There was never more preaching and less following, the people live so
amiss:
But what is he that may not on the sabbath day attend to hear Gods word?
But we will rather run to bowls, sit at the alehouses, than one hour afford:

Telling a tale of Robin hood, sitting at Cards, playing at
kettles, or else some other vain thing:
That I fear Gods vengeance on our heads it will bring,
God grant amendment, but Lady Conscience I pray,
In my behalf Lucre do what ye may.

sp.speaker: Simpli.
sp.l: Mass my cousin can say his book well, I had not thought it,
He is worthy to have a Benefice, and it will hit.

sp.speaker: Consci.
sp.l: God be blessed Sincerity, for the good comfort I have of thee:
I would it lay in us to pleasure such believe me.

We will do what we can: But
vltra posse non est esse,
you know,
It is Lucre that hath brought us poor souls so low.
For we have sold our house, we are brought so poor:
And fear by her shortly to be shut out of door.
Yet to subscribe our name we will with all our heart,
Perchance for our sakes some thing she will impart.
Come hither Simplicity, let me write on thy back .

sp.speaker: Simpli.
sp.l: Here is the right picture of that fellow that sits in the corner.

body.stage: Enter Hospitalitie while she is a writing.

sp.speaker: Hospi.
sp.l: Lady, methinks you are busy.

sp.speaker: Consci.
sp.p:
I have done sir, I was setting my hand to a letter to Lucre for our
friend Sincerity.
But I would Lady Love were here too.

sp.speaker: Hospi.
sp.l: She is at home with me, but if you please so much in her behalf I will do .

sp.speaker: Consci.
sp.l: I pray heartily, and it shall suffice the turn well enough:
Good Simplicity, once more thy body do bow.

sp.speaker: Simpli.
sp.l: I think I shall serve to be a washing block for you.
I would do it for you, but I am afraid yonder boy will mock me.

sp.speaker: Hospi.
sp.l: No I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Consci.
sp.l: Here take thy letters Sincerity, and I wish them prosperous to thee.

sp.speaker: Sincer.
sp.l: I yield you most hearty thanks my good Lady.

sp.speaker: Hospi.
sp.l: Lady Conscience, pleaseth it you to walk home to dinner with me?

sp.speaker: Cons.
sp.l: I give you thanks my good friend Hospitality.
But I pray you sir, have you invited to dinner any stranger?

sp.speaker: Hospi.
sp.l: No sure, none but Lady Love, and 3. or 4. honest neighbours.

sp.speaker: Simpli.
sp.l: Mass my Lady is gotten to dinner already,
I believe she rose at ten o'clock she is so hungry.
What if I should come to dinner, hast thou any good cheer?

sp.speaker: Hospi.
sp.l: I have bread and bear, one joint of meat, and welcome thy best fare.

sp.speaker: Simpli.
sp.l: Why, art thou called Hospitality, and hast no better cheer than that?
I will tell thee, if thou hast no more meat for so many, they will ne'er be fat.
What if my cousin, nay I myself alone, to dinner should come?
Where should my Lady and the rest dine? for I could eat up every crumb.
Thou art an old miser, dost thou keep no better fare in thy house?

Hast no great Bag Pudding, no Hogs face, that is called
Sows?
My friend, Hospitality doth not consist in great fare and banqueting,
But in doing good the Poor, and to yield them some refreshing.
Therefore if thou and Sincerity will come and take part,
Such as I have I will give you with a free and willing heart.

sp.speaker: Simpli.
sp.l: He speaks well cousin, let us go to dinner with him.
The old man shall not think but we will pleasure him.
Faith he might have richer fellows, than we to take his part,

But he shall never have better eating fellows if he would swelled his
heart.
Here be them will eat with the proudest of them.
I am sure my mother said I could eat so much as five men.
Nay I have a gift for eating I tell ye .
For our Maids would never believe I put all the meat in my belly.
But I have spied a knave, my Lady Lucre's cogging man,
give me your letters cousin, I will prefer ye if I can.

sp.speaker: Sincer.
sp.l: Dissimulation, out upon him, he shall be no spokesman for me.

sp.speaker: Sympli.
sp.l: Why then you are a fool cousin Sincerity,
Give me them , I tell ye, I know he will do it for me.

sp.speaker: Sinceri.
sp.l: Seeing thou wilt have it, here receive it, but yet it grieves my heart,
That this dissembling wretch should speak on my part.

sp.speaker: Simpli.
sp.l: Hear ye sir, I would bequest to liver this liver this letter,
To your good wholesome mistress Lady Lucre.

sp.speaker: Dissim.
sp.l: Where hadst thou it tell me?

sp.speaker: Simpli.
sp.l: Marie of my cousin Sincerity.

sp.speaker: Dissim.
sp.l: Why I have nothing to do in it, it is not to me thou shouldest come,

I have not to do with Sincerity's matters, it is my fellow Symonies
room.

sp.speaker: Sinceri.
sp.l: Thou art akin to the Lawyer, thou wilt do nothing without a fee,
But thou, Fraud, Usury, nor yet Simony, shall do nothing for me.
If thou wilt do it do it, if thou wilt not choose,
Both thee and their dealing I hate and refuse.

sp.speaker: Dissim.
sp.l: Why, and I am not bound to thee so far as knave go ,
And therefore in despite of thee and thy cousin there thy letters be.
What, thinkest thou by captious words to make me do it?
Let them deliver your letters that hath a stomach to it.

sp.speaker: Simpli.
sp.l: Faith cousin he is such a testern and proud sembling knave,
That he will do nothing les some bribery he have .
There is a great many such promoting knaves, that gets their living,
With nothing else but facing, lying, swearing, and flattering.

Why he has a face like a black Dog, and blusheth like the back side
of a chimney,
It was not for nothing thy Godfathers a cogging name gave thee.
But here comes his Mistress Lady Lucre,
Now cousin I will liver your letter.
Mistress Lady Lucre here is a letter for ye.

sp.speaker: Lucar.
sp.l: Hast thou a letter for me?

sp.speaker: Simpli.
sp.l: Aye by Saint Marie.
How say you cousin, she reads your letter?
If you can flatter perhaps ye shall speed better.

sp.speaker: Sinceri.
sp.l: Thou speakest the truth Simplicity, for flatterers nowadays ,
Live Gentlemen-like, and with prating get praise.

sp.speaker: Lucar.
sp.l: Sir, I have read the tenure of your letter, wherein I find,
That at the request of Love and Conscience I should show myself kind
In bestowing some spiritual living on ye, parsonage, or Benefice,
It seems it stands greatly in need , as appears by this.
And trust me I would do for you, but it lies not in me ,
For I have referred all such matters to my servant Simony.
You must speak to him, and if you can get his good will,
Then be sure of mine, their minds to fulfil.

sp.speaker: Since.
sp.l: Lady, I shall never get his good will, because I want ability,
For he will do nothing except I bring money.
And if you grant it not, then it is past all doubt,
I shall be never the better, but go quite without.

sp.speaker: Dissim.
sp.l: Madam, I can tell what you may give ,
Not hurting yourself whereby he may live ,
And without my fellow Symonies consent,
If to follow my mind you are any whit bent.

sp.speaker: Lucar.
sp.l:
Pray thee what is it? for thou knowest while for their house I am in
bargaining,
If it be never so little, I must seem to do some thing.

sp.speaker: Dissim.
sp.l: Why, have not you the parsonage of Saint. Nihil to bestow?
If you give him that, Simony shall never know .

sp.speaker: Lucar.
sp.l: Indeed thou sayst true: draw near Sincerity,
Lo, for their sakes I will bestow frankly on thee.
I will give thee the Parsonage of Saint. Nihil, to pleasure them withal,
And such another to it, if thou watch till it fall.

sp.speaker: Simpli.
sp.l:
My Lady axes you when you will take possession of your house, and
lend the rest of the money.

sp.speaker: Lucar.
sp.l: What are they so hasty? belike they spent it merrily.

sp.speaker: Simpli.
sp.l:
Faith no, for they would eat it if they could get it, when they are
hungry.
But you may be happy, for you have sped well today,
You may thank God and good company that you came this way.
The Parsonage of Saint. Michele, byrLady if you have nothing else,
You shall be sure of a living, beside a good ring of Bells.
Cousin I will tell thee what thou shalt do, sell the bells, and make money.

sp.speaker: Sincer.
sp.l: Thou mayst well be Simplicity, for thou showest thy folly.
I have a Parsonage, but what? of Saint. Nihil, and Nihil is nothing,
Then where is the Church, or any bells for to ring?
Thou understandest her not, she was set for to flout,
I thought coming in their names I should go without.
It is easy to see that Lucre loves not Love and Conscience:
But God I trust will one day yield her just recompense.

sp.speaker: Sympli.
sp.l: Cousin, you said that some thing to me you would give ,
When you had gotten preferment of Lucre to live :
And I trust you will remember your poor cousin Simplicity,
You know to Lady Conscience and everybody I did speak for you.

sp.speaker: Sinceri.
sp.l: Good Simplicity hold thy peace, my state is yet nought,
I will help thee sure, if ever I get aught .
But here comes Sir Nicholas Nemo, to him I will go,
And see if for their sakes he will anything bestow.

sp.speaker: Nemo.
sp.l: You come from Love and Conscience, as seemeth me here ,
My special good friends, whom I account of most dear.
And you are called Sincerity, your state shows the same:
You are welcome to me for their sakes, and for your own name.
And for their sakes you shall see what I will do for you,
Without Dissimulation, Fraud, Usury, or Simony:
For they will do nothing without some kind of gain,
Such cankered corruption in their hearts doth remain.

But come in to dinner with me, and when you have dined,
you shall have .

sp.speaker: Sinceri.
sp.l:
You shall have , but what? a living that is blown down with the
wind.

sp.speaker: Simpli.
sp.l: Now cousin dismember your friends, seeing two livings you have :
One that this man promised, and another that Lady Lucre gave.
Mass you will be a jolly man, if you had three or four more,
Let us beg apace cousin and we shall get great store.

Do thou get some more letters, and I will get them scribed of Mistress Love
and Conscience,
And we will go beg livings together, we will beg no small pence.
How sayst thou cousin Sincerity, would do so much ,
If we can speak fair and semble, we shall be plaguey rich.

sp.speaker: Sinceri.
sp.l: Good Simplicity content thee, I am never the better for this,
I must of force leave off, for I see how vain it is.
It boots not Sincerity to sue for relief,
So few regard that to me is a grief.
This was Nicholas Nemo, and no man hath no place,
Then how can I speed well in this heavy case.
If no man bid me to dinner, when shall I dine?
Or how shall I find him, where, when, and at what time?
Wherefore the relief I have had, and shall have , is small,
But to speak truth, the relief is nothing at all.
But come Simplicity, let us go see what may be had,
Sincerity in these days was sure born to be sad.

sp.speaker: Simpli.
sp.l:
Come let us go to dinner cousin, for the Gentleman I think hath almost
dined.
But if I get victuals enough, I warrant you I will not be behind.

sp.speaker: Since.
sp.l: What if thou canst not get it, then how wilt thou eat?

sp.speaker: Simpli.
sp.l:
Marry on this fashion, with both hands at once, ye shall see when I get
meat.

sp.speaker: Sinceri.
sp.l: Why his name was Nemo, and Nemo hath no being.

sp.speaker: Simpli.
sp.l: I believe cousin you be not hungry, that you stand prating.
Faith I will go do him a pleasure, because he hath need ,
Why if he will needs have his meat eat, he shall see how I will feed.
I believe he will not bid me come again to him,
Mass if he do, he shall find a fellow that has his eating.

body.stage:
Exeunt ambo.
Enter Vsury and Conscience.

sp.speaker: Vsury.
sp.l: Lady Conscience, is there anybody within your house can you tell?

sp.speaker: Consci.
sp.l: There is nobody at all be ye sure, I know certainly well.

sp.speaker: Vsury.
sp.l: You know when one comes to take possession of any piece of Land,

There must not be one within, for against the order of Law it doth
stand.

Therefore I thought good to ask you, but I pray you think not
amiss:

For both you, and almost all others knows, that an old custom
it is.

sp.speaker: Consci.
sp.l: You say truth, take possession when you please, good leave I render ye,

Doubt you not, there is neither man, woman nor child, that will or
shall hinder you.

sp.speaker: Vsery.
sp.l: Why then I will be bold to enter.

sp.speaker: Consci.
sp.l: Who is more bold than Usury to venture?
He maketh the matter dangerous where is no need at all,
But he thinks it not perilous to seek every man's fall:
Both he and Lucre hath so pinched us , we know not what to do ,
Were it not for Hospitality, we knew not whither to go .
Great is the misery that we poor Ladies abide,
And much more is the cruelty of Lucre and Usury beside.
O Conscience thou art not accompted of, O Love thou art little set by,
For almost everyone , true love , and pure conscience doth deny:
So hath Lucre crept into the bosom of man, woman, and child,
That everyone doth practise his dear friend to beguile.
But God grant Hospitality be not by them overpressed ,
In whom all our stay and chiefest comfort doth rest:
But Usury hates Hospitality, and cannot him abide,
Because he for the poor and comfortless doth provide.
Here he comes, that hath undone many an honest man,
And daily seeks to destroy, deface, and bring to ruin if he can.
Now sir, have you taken possession as your dear Lady wild you?

sp.speaker: Vsery.
sp.l: I have done it, and I think you have received your money,

But this to you: my Lady wild me to bid you provide some other house
out of hand.

For she would not by her will, have Love and Conscience to dwell in
her land.
Therefore I would wish you to provide ye,
So ye should save charges, for a less house may serve.

sp.speaker: Consci.
sp.l: I pray you heartily let us stay there, and we will be content
To give you ten pound a year, which is the old rent.

sp.speaker: Vsery.
sp.l: Ten pound a year, that were a stale jest:
If I should take the old rent to follow your request,
Nay after forty pound a year, you shall have it for a quarter:
And you may think too, I greatly befriend ye in this matter:
But no longer than for a quarter to you I will set it,
For perhaps my Lady shall sell it, or else to some other will let it.

sp.speaker: Consci.
sp.l: Well, sith we are driven to this hard and bitter drift,
We accept it, and are contented to make bare and hard shift.

sp.speaker: Vsurie.
sp.l: Then get you gone, and see at a day your rent be ready.

sp.speaker: Consci.
sp.l: We must have patience perforce seeing there is no remedy.

sp.speaker: Vsery.
sp.l: I might so well have had after threescore, as such a trifle:
For seeing they were distressed, they would have given largely.
I was a right sot, but I will be overseen no more believe me.

sp.speaker: Merca.
sp.l:
Ah my good
friend
master Usury, by my trot you be very well
met:

Me be much beholding you for your good will, me be in your
debt.

But
me take
your part so much against a scald old churl called
Hospitality:
Did speak against you, and says you bring good honest men to beggary.

sp.speaker: Vsury.
sp.l: I thank Sir, did he speak such evil of me as you now say?
I doubt not but to reward him for his treachery one day.

sp.speaker: Merca.
sp.l:
But I pray tell
me how fare
my Lady all this while?

sp.speaker: Vsury.
sp.l: Marie very well Sir, and here she comes if myself I do not beguile.

sp.speaker: Lucar.
sp.l: What seignior Mercardore I have not seen you many a day,
I marvel what is the cause you kept so long away?

sp.speaker: Merca.
sp.l:
Shall me say to you Madam that me have had much business for you
in hand,
For send away good commodities out of this little Country England:

We have now sent over Brass, Copper, Pewter, and many other
thing :

And for that me shall have for Gentlewoman's fine trifles, that great profit
will bring:

sp.speaker: Lucar.
sp.l:
I perceive you have been mindful of me for which I thank
ye :
But Usury tell me, how have you sped in that you went about?

sp.speaker: Vsery.
sp.l: Indifferently Lady, you need not to doubt,
I have taken possession, and because they were destitute:
I have let it for a quarter my tale to conclude.

Marry I have a little raised the rent, but it is but after forty pound by
the year:
But if it were to let now, I would let it more dear.

sp.speaker: Lucar.
sp.l: Indeed it is but a trifle, it makes no matter,
I force it not greatly, being but for a quarter.

sp.speaker: Merca.
sp.l:
Madonna me tell ye what you shall do , let them to stranger that are
content
To dwell in a little room, and to pay much rent:
For you know that frenchmans and fleminges in this country be many,
So that they make shift to dwell ten houses in one very gladly:

And be content
for pay fifty or three score pound a year,
For that which the Englishmans say twenty mark is too dear.

sp.speaker: Lucar.
sp.l: Why senior Mercadore think you not that I
Have infinite numbers in London that my want doth supply.
Beside in Bristow, Northampton, Norwich, Weschester, Canterbury,
Dover, Sandwich, Rie, Porchmouth, Plimmoth, and many more ,
That great rents upon little room do bestow.
Yes I warrant you, and truly I may thank the strangers for this,
That they have made houses so dear, whereby I live in bliss.
But senior Mercadore, dare you to travel undertake:
And go amongst the Moors, Turks, and Pagans for my sake?

sp.speaker: Merca.
sp.l:
Madonna, me dare
go to the Turks, Moors, Pagans and
more too.
What do me care if me go to the great devil for you.

Command
me Madam, and you shall see plain,

That for your sake me refuse
no pain.

sp.speaker: Lucar.
sp.l: Then senior Mercadore I am forthwith to send ye
From hence, to search for some new toys in Barbary or Turkey,
Such trifles as you think will please wantons best:
For you know in this Country it is their chiefest request.

sp.speaker: Merca.
sp.l: Indeed the Gentlewoman's here buy so much vain toys,

That me strangers laugh
to think wherein they have their Joys:
Faith Madonna me will search all the strange countries me can tell,
But me will have such tinges that please these Gentlewoman's well .

sp.speaker: Lucar.
sp.l: Why then let us provide things ready to haste you away.

sp.speaker: Merca.
sp.l: A voutro commaundamento Madonna me obey.

body.stage:
Exeunt.
Enter Symony and Peter Pleaseman like a Parson.

sp.speaker: Symo.
sp.l: Now proceed with your tale and I will hear thee.

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.l: And so sir as I was about to tell you:
This same Presco, and this same Cracko be both my parishioners now,
And sir they fell out marvelously together about you:
The same Cracko took your part, and said that the Clergy
Was upholden by you, and maintained very worshipfully:
So sir, Presco he would not grant that in no case,
But said that you did corrupt the clergy, and dishonour that holy place.
Now sir I was weary to hear them at such great strife,
For I love to please men so long as I have life:
Therefore I beseech your mastership to speak to Lady Lucre,
That I may be her Chaplain, or else to serve her.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: What is your name?

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.l: Sir Peter.

sp.speaker: Symo.
sp.l: What more?

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.l: Forsooth Pleaseman.

sp.speaker: Symo.
sp.l: Then your name is Sir Peter Pleaseman.

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.l: Aye forsooth.

sp.speaker: Symo.
sp.l: And please woman too now and then.

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.l: You know that homo is indifferent.

sp.speaker: Symo.
sp.l: Now surely a good scholar in my judgment.
I pray at what University were ye?

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.l: Of no University truly:

Marry I have gone to school in a College, where I have studied
two or three places of Divinity:
And all for Lady Lucre's sake, sir, you may steadfastly believe me.

sp.speaker: Symo.
sp.l: Nay I believe ye, but of what religion are you can ye tell?

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.l: Marry sir of all religions, I know not myself very well.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: You are a Protestant now, and I think to that you will grant.

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.l:
Indeed I have been a Catholic, marry now for the most part a
Protestant.
But and if my service may please her, hark in your ear sir,
I warrant you my Religion shall not offend her.

sp.speaker: Symo.
sp.l: You say well, but if I help you to such great preferment,

Would you be willing, that for my pain I shall have yearly half the
gain.
For it is reason you know, that if I help you to a living,
That you should me be somewhat beholding.

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.l: Aye sir and reason good, I will be as your mastership please.
I care not what you do , so I may live at ease.

sp.speaker: Symo.
sp.l:
Then this man is answered: Sir Peter Pleaseman, come in
with me.
And I will prefer ye straightway to my Lady.

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.l: O Sir I thank ye.

body.stage:
Exeunt.
Enter Simplicitie, with a basket on his Arme.

sp.speaker: Simpli.
sp.l: You think I am going to market to buy roost meat, do ye not?
I thought so, but you are deceived: for I wot what I wot.
I am neither going to the Butchers to buy Veal, Mutton or Beef,

But I am going to a bloodsucker, and who is it? faith Usury that
thief.

Why sirs, it was no marckle he undoed my father that was called
Plain Dealing.
When he undone my Lady and Conscience too with his usuring.
I will tell ye sirs, trust him not, for he will flatter bonacion and sore,
Till he has gotten the Bakers vantage, then he will turn you out of door.

sp.speaker: Dissim.
sp.l: Simplicity, now of my honesty very heartily well met.

sp.speaker: Simpli.
sp.l:
What Semblacion swear not, for thou swarest by that thou couldst
not get.
Thou have honesty now? thy honesty is quite gone:
Marry thou hadst honesty at xi. of the clock, and went from thee at noon:
Why how canst thou have honesty, when it dare not come nigh thee?

I warrant Semlacion: he that has less honesty than thou may defy
thee:
Thou hast honesty sir-reverence, come out dog, where art thou?
Even as much honesty as had my mothers great hoggish sow:
No faith thou mayst put out my eye with honesty, if thou hadst it here,
Hast not left it at the Alehouse, in gage for a pot of strong beer?

sp.speaker: Dissim.
sp.l: Pray thee leave prating Simplicity, and tell me what thou hast there?

sp.speaker: Simpli.
sp.l: Why, it is nothing for thee, thou dost not deal with such kind of ware.

Sirrah there is no deceit in a bag pudding, is there? nor in a plain
pudding pie:
But there is deceit and knavery too in thy fellow that is called Usury.

Sirrah I will tell thee, I will not tell thee, and yet I will tell thee, now I
member me too:
Canst tell, or wouldst thou know whither with this parliament I go?
Faith even to suck-swill thy fellow Usury I am sent,

With my Lady Loves gown, and Lady Conscience too, for a quarters
rent.

sp.speaker: Dissim.
sp.l: Alas poor Lady Love , art thou driven so low?
Some little pittance on thee I will bestow.
Hold Simplicity, carry her three or four Ducats from me,
And commend me to her even very heartily.

sp.speaker: Sympli.
sp.l:
Duck eggs, yes I will carry them , if it were as many as this would
hold.

sp.speaker: Dissim.
sp.l: Tush thou knowest not what I mean, take this, it is gold.

sp.speaker: Simpli.
sp.l:
Mass it is gold indeed, why, wilt send away thy gold, hast no more
need ?
I think thou art grown plaguey rich with thy dissembling trade,
But I will carry my Lady the gold, for this will make her well apaid.

sp.speaker: Dissim.
sp.l:
And sirrah, carry Lady Loves gown back again , for my fellow
Usury
Shall not have her gown, I am sure so much he will befriend me .

sp.speaker: Simpli.
sp.l: But what shall Conscience gown do , shall I carry that back again too?

sp.speaker: Dissi.
sp.l: Nay, let Conscience gown and skin to Usury go.
If nobody cared for Conscience more than I,
They would hang her up like Bacon in a chimney to dry.

sp.speaker: Simpli.
sp.l: Faith I told thee thou caredest not for Conscience nor honesty:
I think indeed it will never be the death of thee.
But I will go conspatch my errant so soon as I can I tell ye,
For now I have gold, I would fain have some good meat in my belly.

sp.speaker: Dissim.
sp.l: Nay I will hie me after, that I may send back Lady Loves gown,
For I would not have Love bought quite out of town.
Marry for Conscience tut, I care not two straws,
Why I should take care for her, I know no kind of cause.

sp.speaker: Hospi.
sp.l:
O what shall I say? Usury hath undone me, and now he hates me
to the death,
And seeks by all means possible for to bereave me of breath.
I cannot rest in any place, but he hunts and follows me everywhere ,
That I know no place to abide, I live so much in fear.
But out alas, here comes he that will shorten my days.

sp.speaker: Vsurie.
sp.l:
O have I caught your old gray beard, you be the man whom the
people so praise:
You are a frank Gentleman, and full of liberality,
Why, who had all the praise in London or England, but Master. Hospitality?
But I will Master you now I will hold you a groat.

sp.speaker: Hospi.
sp.l: What will you kill me?

sp.speaker: Vsery.
sp.l: No, I will do nothing but out thy throat.

sp.speaker: Hospi.
sp.l: O help, help, help, for Gods sake.

sp.speaker: Consci.
sp.l: What lamentable cry was that I heard one make?

sp.speaker: Hospi.
sp.l: O Lady Conscience, now or never help me.

sp.speaker: Consci.
sp.l: Why, what wilt thou do with him Usury?

sp.speaker: Usury.
sp.l: What will I do with him? marry cut his throat, and then no more.

sp.speaker: Consci.
sp.p:
O dost thou not consider that thou shalt dearly answer for Hospitality
that good member, refrain it therefore.

sp.speaker: Usury.
sp.l: Refrain me no refraining, nor answer me no answering,
The matter is answered well enough in this thing.

sp.speaker: Consci.
sp.p:
For Gods sake spare him, for country sake spare him, for pity sake spare
him, for Love sake spare him, for Conscience sake forbear him.

sp.speaker: Vsury.
sp.l: Let country, pity, Love , Conscience, and all go in respect of myself ,
He shall die, come ye feeble wretch, I will dress ye like an elf.

sp.speaker: Consci.
sp.l: But yet Usury, consider the lamentable cry of the poor,
For lack of Hospitality, fatherless children are turned out of door.
Consider again the complaint of the sick, blind and lame,
That will cry the Lord for vengeance on thy head in his name.
Is the fear of God so far from thee that thou hast no feeling at all?

O repent Usury, leave Hospitality, and for mercy at the Lords hand
call.

sp.speaker: Vsury.
sp.l: Leave prating Conscience, thou canst not mollify my heart,
He shall in spite of thee and all other feel his deadly smart.
Yet I will not commit the murder openly,
But hale the villain into a corner, and so kill him secretly.
Come ye miserable drudge, and receive thy death.

sp.speaker: Hospi.
sp.l: Help good Lady, help, he will stop my breath.

sp.speaker: Consci.
sp.l: Alas I would help thee, but I have not the power.

sp.speaker: Hospi.
sp.l:
Farewell Lady Conscience, you shall have Hospitality in London nor
England no more.

sp.speaker: Consci.
sp.l: O help, help, help, some good body.

sp.speaker: Dissim.
sp.l: Who is that calls for help so hastily?

sp.speaker: Consci.
sp.l: Out alas thy fellow Usury hath killed Hospitality.

sp.speaker: Simpli.
sp.l: Now Gods blessing on his heart, why it was time that he was dead,
He was an old churl, with never a good tooth in his head.
And he ne'er kept no good cheer that I could see:

For if one had not come at dinner time, he should have gone away
hungry.
I could never get my belly full of meat,
He had nothing but beef, bread, and cheese for me to eat.

Now I would have had some Pies, or bag puddings with great
lumps of fat:
But I warrant ye he did keep my mouth well enough from that.
Faith if he be dead he is dead, let him go to the devil, if he will,
Or if he will not go thither, let him even lie there still.
I will ne'er make wamentation for an old churl

For he has been a great while, and now it is time that he were out of
the world.

sp.speaker: Lucar.
sp.l: What Conscience, thou lookest like a poor pigeon pulled of late.

sp.speaker: Consci.
sp.l: What Lucre, thou lookest like a whore full of deadly hate.

sp.speaker: Lucar.
sp.l: Alas Conscience I am sorry for thee, but I cannot weep.

sp.speaker: Consci.
sp.l: Alas Lucre, I am sorry for thee, that thou canst no hostie keep.
But such as thou art, such are thy attenders on thee,

As appears by thy servant Usury, that hath killed that good member
Hospitality.

sp.speaker: Simpli.
sp.l: Faith Hospital is killed, and hath made his will,
And hath given Dissimulation three trees upon an high hill.

sp.speaker: Lucar.
sp.l: Come hither Dissimulation, and hie you hence so fast as you may,
And help thy fellow Usury to convey himself out of the way.
Further, will the Justices, if they chance to see him, not to know him,
Or know him, not by any means to hinder him.
And they shall command thrice so much at my hand,
Go, trudge, run, out, away, how dost thou stand?

sp.speaker: Dissim.
sp.l: Nay good Lady, send my fellow Simony,
For I have an earnest suite to ye .

sp.speaker: Lucar.
sp.l: Then Simony go do what I have wild.

sp.speaker: Symo.
sp.l: I run Madam, your mind shall be fulfilled.

sp.speaker: Cons.
sp.l:
Well well Lucre,
Audeo, et taceo,
I see and say nothing:
But I fear the plague of God on thy head it will bring.

sp.speaker: Dissim.
sp.l: Good Lady grant that Love be your waiting Maid,
For I think being brought so low, she will be well apaid.

sp.speaker: Lucar.
sp.l: Speakest thou in good earnest, or dost thou but dissemble?
I know not how to have thee, thou art so variable.

sp.speaker: Dissim.
sp.l:
Lady, though my name be Dissimulation, yet I speak bona fide
now ,
If it please you my petitions to allow.

sp.speaker: Lucar.
sp.l: Stand by, I will answer thee anon. What news Simony,
Bringest thou of thy fellow Usury?

sp.speaker: Symo.
sp.l: Marry Madam good news: for Usury lies close
Hid in a rich man's house, that will not let him loose,
Until they see the matter brought to a good end.
For Usury in this country hath many a good friend.
And late I saw Hospitality carried to burying.

sp.speaker: Lucar.
sp.l: I pray thee tell me , who were they that followed him?

sp.speaker: Symo.
sp.l: There were many of the Clergy, and many of the Nobility,
And many right worshipful rich Citizens,
Substantial, gracious, and very wealthy Farmers.
But to see how the poor followed him it was a wonder,
Never yet at any burial I have seen such a number.

sp.speaker: Lucar.
sp.l: But what say the people of the murder?

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: Many are sorry and say it is great pity that he was slain,
But who be they? the poor beggarly people that so complain:
As for the other, they say it was a cruel bloody fact,
But I perceive none will hinder the murderer for this cruel act.

sp.speaker: Lucar.
sp.l: It is well, I am glad of it, now Dissimulation if you can get Loves good will,
I am contented with all my heart to grant there until.

sp.speaker: Dissim.
sp.l: I thank you good Lady, and I doubt not but she
With a little entreaty will thereto agree.

sp.speaker: Simpli.
sp.l: Now I have it in my breeches, for I can tell,
That I and my Lady with mistress Lucre shall dwell.
But if I be her serving fellow, and dwell there,
I must learn to cog, lie, foist and swear.
And sure I shall never learn, marie if it were to lie a bed all day,
I know to that kind of living I can give a good say.
Or if it were to eat ones meat, then I knew what I had to do:
How say ye sirrah, can I not? I will be drudge by you.

sp.speaker: Lucar.
sp.l: Now to you little mouse, did I not tell you before,
That I should ere it were long turn you both out of door?
How say you pretty soul, is it come to pass, yea or no?
I think I have pulled your peacocks plumes somewhat low.
And yet you be so stout as though you felt no grief,
But I know ere it be long you will come pulling to me for relief.

sp.speaker: Consci.
sp.l: Well Lucre well, you know pride will have a fall:
What advantageth it thee to win the world, and lose thy soul withal?
Yet better it is to live with little, and keep a conscience clear,
Which is to God a Sacrifice, and accounted of most dear.

sp.speaker: Lucar.
sp.l: Nay Conscience, if you be bookish I mean to leave ye,
And the cold ground to comfort your feet I bequeath ye.
Me think you being so deeply learned, may do well to keep a school,
Why, I have seen so cunning a Clarke in time to prove a fool.

sp.speaker: Simpli.
sp.l: Sirrah, if thou shouldest marry my Lady thou wouldst keep her brave,
For I think now thou art a plaguey rich knave.

sp.speaker: Dissim.
sp.l: Rich I am, but as for knave keep to thyself ,
Come give me my Ladies gown thou ass-headed elf.

sp.speaker: Simpli.
sp.l: Why I will go with thee, for I must dwell with my Lady.

sp.speaker: Dissim.
sp.l:
Pack, hence, away, Jack Drums entertainment, she will none
of thee.

sp.speaker: Simpli.
sp.l: This is as my cousin and I went to Master. Nemos house,
There was nobody to bid a dog drink, or to change a man a louse.
But Lady Conscience (nay who there) scratch that name away,
Is she a Lady that is turned out of all her bewray?
Do not be called no more Lady, and if you be wise,

For everybody will mock you, and say you be not worth two
butterflies .

sp.speaker: Consci.
sp.l: What remedy Simplicity? I cannot do withal.
But what shall we go do, or whereto shall we fall?

sp.speaker: Simpli.
sp.l: Why to our vitals, I know nothing else we have to do,
And mark if I cannot eat twenty times as much as you.

sp.speaker: Consci.
sp.l: If I go lie in an Inn, I shall be sore grieved to see,

The deceit of the Ostler, the polling of the Tapster, as in most houses
of lodging they be.

If in a Brewers house, at the overplenty of water, and scarceness of
malt I should grieve,

Whereby to enrich themselves , all other unsavoury thin drink
they deceive.
If in a Tanners house, with his great deceit in tanning
If in a Weavers house, with his great cozening in weaving.
If in a Bakers house, with light bread, and very evil working:

If in a Chandlers, with deceitful weights, false measures, selling for
a halfpenny that is scant worth a farthing.

And if in an Alehouse, with the great resort of poor unthrifts,
that with swearing at the Cards consume their lives,

Having greater delight to spend a shilling that way,
than a groat at home to sustain their needy children and wives.
For which I judge it best for me to get some solitary place,
Where I may with patience this my heavy cross embrace.
And learn to sell broom, whereby to get my living,
Using that as a quiet mean to keep myself from begging.
Wherefore Simplicity if thou wilt do the like,
Settle thyself to it, and with true labour thy living do seek.

sp.speaker: Simpli.
sp.l: No faith misters Conscience, I will not, for if I should sell broom,
The Maiden would cousin me too competually with their old shoen.
And too I cannot work, and you would hang me out of the way,
For when I was a miller, Will did grind the meal while I did play.

Therefore I will have as easy an occupation as I had when my Father
was alive,

Faith I will go even a-begging , why it is a good trade, a man shall be sure to
thrive.

For I am sure my prayers will get bread and cheese, and my singing will
get me drink,

Then shall not I do better then Misters Conscience? tell me as you
think .
Therefore God Pan in the kitchen, and God Pot in the buttery,
Come and resist me, that I may sing with the more meliositie.
But sirs mark my cold countenance when I begin,

But yonder is a fellow that gapes to bite me or else to eat that which I
sing.
Why thou art a fool canst not thou keep thy mouth strait together?
And when it comes snap at it as my fathers dog would do at a liver.
But thou art so greedy,
That thou thinkest to eat it before it come nigh thee.
Simplicity singes it, and experience doth prove,
No biding in London for Conscience and Love.

l.emph: where Conscience comes not once a year:
And Love so welcome to every town,
as wind that blows the houses down .
Sing down a-down, down, down, down.

sp.l: Simplicity singes it and experience doth prove,
No dwelling in London, no biding in London for Conscience and Love.

sp.speaker: Simpli.
sp.l:
Now sirrah hast eaten up my song? and ye have ye shall eat no more
today,

For everybody may see your belly is grown bigger with eating up our
play:
He has filled his belly, but I am never a whit the better,

Therefore I will go seek some vitals, and member for eating up my song
you shall be my debtor.

body.stage:
(Exit.)
Enter Mercadorus the Merchaunt and Gerontus a Iewe.

sp.speaker: Geron.
sp.l: But senior Mercadorus tell me, did ye serve me well or no?
That having gotten my money would seem the country to forgo:
You know I lent you two thousand ducats for three months space,

And ere the time came you got another thousand by flattery and your
smooth face.
So when the time came that I should have received my money,
You were not to be found but was fled out of the country:
Surely if we that be Jews should deal so one with another ,
We should not be trusted again of our own brother:

But many of you Christians make no conscience to falsify your faith and
break your day.

I should have been paid at three months end, and now it is two year
you have been away.
sp.p:
Well I am glad you be come again to Turkey, now I trust I shall receive
the interest of you so well as the principal.

sp.speaker: Merca.
sp.l:
good
master Geronto pray heartily bear with me a little while,
And me shall pay ye all without any deceit or guile:

Me have
much business for by pretty knacks to send to England,
sp.p:
Good
sir bear with me four or five days, me will dispatch your money out of
hand.

sp.speaker: Geron.
sp.l:
Senior Mercadore, I know no reason why, because you have dealt
with me so ill,
Sure you did it not for need , but of set purpose and will:

And I tell ye to bear with ye four or five days goes sore against my
mind,
Least you should steal away and forget to leave my money behind.

sp.speaker: Merca.
sp.l:
Pray heartily do think
no such thing my good friend of me,
By my trot and faith me will pay you all every penny.

sp.speaker: Geron.
sp.l: Well I will take your faith and troth once more, I will trust to your honesty
In hope that for my long tarrying you will deal well with me:

Tell me what ware you would buy for England, such necessaries
as they lack?

sp.speaker: Merca.
sp.l: O no lack, some pretty fine toy or some fantastic new knack,
For the Gentlewoman's in England buy much tinges for fantasy:

You pleasure
me sir, what me mean for there buy.

sp.speaker: Geron.
sp.l:
I understand you sir, but keep touch with me, and I will bring you to
great store,
Such as I perceive you came to this country for:

As Musk, Amber, sweet Powders, fine Odours, pleasant perfumes,
and many such toys:
Wherein I perceive consisteth that country gentlewoman's Joys.

Besides I have Diamonds, Rubies, Emerodes, Sapphires, Smaradines,
Opals, Onacles, Jacinths, Agates, Turkasir, and almost of
all kind of precious stones:

And many more fit things to suck away money from such green-headed
wantons.

sp.speaker: Merca.
sp.l: Fatta my good friend me thank you most heartily always,

Me shall
content your debt within this two or three day.

sp.speaker: Geron.
sp.l:
Well look you do keep your promise, and another time you shall
command me:
Come, go we home where our commodities you may at pleasure see.

body.stage:
(Exeunt.)
Enter Conscience with broomes at her back singing
as followeth.

sp.l: New brooms, green brooms, will you by any,
Come maidens, come quickly, let me take a penny.
My brooms are not steeped,
but very well bound:
My brooms be not crooked,
but smooth cut and round.
I wish it should please you,
to buy of my broom:
Then would it well ease me,
if market were done.
Have you any old boots,
or any old shoen:
Pouch-rings or Buskins,
to cope for new broom.
If so you have maidens,
I pray you bring hither:
That you and I friendly,
may bargain together.
New brooms, green brooms, will you buy any:
Come Maidens, come quickly, let me take a penny.
Thus am I driven to make a virtue of necessity
And seeing God almighty will have it so, I embrace it thankfully:
Desiring God to mollify and lessen Usuries hard heart,
That the poor people, feel not the like penury and smart:
But Usury is made tolerable amongst Christians as a necessary thing.

So that going beyond the limits of our law, they extort, and many to
misery bring.

But if we should follow Gods law we should not receive above that we
lend.
For if we lend for reward, how can we say we are our neighbours friend?
O how blessed shall that man be that lends without abuse:
But thrice accursed shall he be that greatly covets use:
For he that covet overmuch unsatiate is his mind,
So that to perjury and cruelty, he holy is inclined:
Wherewith they sore oppress the poor by divers sundry ways,
Which makes them cry the Lord to shorten cutthroats days:
Paule calleth them thieves that doth not give the needy of their store,
And thrice accursed are they that take one penny from the poor:
But while I stand reasoning thus I forget my market clean,
And sith God hath ordained this way, I am to use the mean.

Have ye any old shoes, or have ye any boots, have ye any buskins, or will
ye buy any broom.

Who bargain or chop with conscience, what will no customer
come?

sp.speaker: Vsury.
sp.l: Who is it that cries brooms, what cons. selling brooms about the street?

sp.speaker: Consci.
sp.l: What Usury, it is great pity thou art unhanged yet.

sp.speaker: Vsury.
sp.l: Believe me Conscience, it grieves me thou art brought so low.

sp.speaker: Consci.
sp.l: Believe me Usury it grieves me thou wast not hanged long ago,
For if thou hadst been hanged before thou slewest Hospitality,
Thou hadst not made me and thousands more to feel like poverty.

sp.speaker: Lucar.
sp.l: Methought I heard one cry brooms along the door.

sp.speaker: Vsery.
sp.l:
Aye marry Madam it was Conscience, who seems to be offended at
me very sore.

sp.speaker: Lucar.
sp.l: Alas Conscience art thou become a poor broomwife?

sp.speaker: Consc.
sp.l: Alas Lucre wilt thou continue a harlot all days of thy life?

sp.speaker: Lucar.
sp.l: Alas I think it is a grief to thee that thou art so poor.

sp.speaker: Consci.
sp.l:
Alas Lucre I think it is no pain to thee that thou still playest the
whore.

sp.speaker: Lucar.
sp.l:
Well well Conscience that sharp tongue of thine hath not been thy
furtherance.

If thou hadst kept thy tongue, thou hadst kept thy friend, and not have
had such hindrance:
